case_vignette: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, comes to the physician because of left ankle swelling for 2 months. She notes that the swelling is present throughout the day and decreases when she goes to sleep. One year ago, she has had an episode of deep venous thrombosis after the delivery of her third child. Her prepregnancy BMI was 34 kg/m2. Examination shows distended, tortuous veins in the legs bilaterally and pitting edema of the left ankle. There are erythematous scaling patches on the medial side of the left ankle. Duplex ultrasonography is performed.
question: Which  directions of blood flow would most likely confirm the diagnosis?
correct_ans: popliteal vein to small saphenous vein

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient comes in with swelling in their left ankle that has been present for 2 months, and it decreases in size when they are sleeping. The patient denies any shortness of breath or chest pain associated with the swelling.
trial_0.vignette_mcq:
The correct answer is: Great saphenous vein to femoral vein.

This symptomatology and examination findings are consistent with chronic venous insufficiency, specifically post-thrombotic syndrome. The most common site of deep vein thrombosis in the lower extremities is the common femoral vein or the iliofemoral system. Chronic venous insufficiency results from damage to the valves in the deep veins, leading to reflux and incompetence. The great saphenous vein, which is the largest superficial vein in the lower extremity, communicates with the deep venous system at the level of the saphenofemoral junction. Therefore, the reflux and incompetence in the deep veins would result in increased pressure and backflow in the great saphenous vein, leading to the clinical presentation of post-thrombotic syndrome.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The diagnosis is likely Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT) with post-thrombotic syndrome. In DVT, blood flow is obstructed in the deep veins, leading to venous hypertension and edema. Therefore, the absence of blood flow or reversed flow in the deep veins on duplex ultrasonography would most likely confirm the diagnosis.

This symptom description is consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the great saphenous vein, which can cause swelling in the ankle that resolves with dependent positioning. This symptom is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the great saphenous vein, which is commonly seen in the lower extremities. DVT can cause swelling and pain in the affected limb, worsening with activity and improving with rest. The diagnosis of DVT is typically confirmed through imaging studies such as ultrasound or venography, which can visualize the blood clot in the affected vein. In this case, the most likely vein involved is the great saphenous vein, which drains blood from the leg and empties into the femoral vein.

DVT typically affects the deep veins of the lower extremities, and ultrasound is the gold standard for its diagnosis.
